2 civilians killed{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/breakingnews/234020/1-villager-killed-2-wounded-in-surin|title=Bangkok Post : The world windows to Thailand|publisher=Bangkokpost.com|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} }} The '''Cambodian–Thai border dispute''' began in June 2008 as the latest round of a century-long dispute between Cambodia and Thailand involving the area surrounding the 11th century [[Preah Vihear Temple]], in the [[Dângrêk Mountains]] between the [[Choam Khsant District|Choam Khsant]] district in the [[Preah Vihear Province|Preah Vihear]] Province of northern Cambodia and the [[Amphoe Kantharalak|Kantharalak]] district (''[[amphoe]]'') in [[Sisaket Province]] of [[northeastern Thailand]]. According to the Cambodian ambassador to the United Nations, the most recent dispute began on 15 July 2008 when about 50 Thai soldiers moved into the Keo Sikha Kiri Svara pagoda vicinity which he claims is located in Cambodia's territory about {{convert|300|m}} from the Temple of Preah Vihear.[https://web.archive.org/20090511123927/http://www.un.int/cambodia/Bulletin_Files/July08/Letter_18_Jul.pdf] Thailand claims the demarcation has not yet been completed for the external parts of the area adjacent to the temple, which was adjudged to be Cambodian by a nine to three decision of the [[International Court of Justice]] (ICJ) in 1962.'''The Nation Newspaper'''. August 5, 2008. VOLUME 33 NO 51950 By August 2008, the dispute had expanded to the 13th century [[Prasat Ta Muen Thom|Ta Moan temple]] complex {{convert|153|km}} west of Preah Vihear ({{coord|14|20|57|N|103|15|59|E|}}), where Cambodia has accused Thai troops of occupying a temple complex it claims is on Cambodian land. The Thai foreign ministry denied that any troops had moved into that area until several were killed in an encounter in April 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.tamoan.net/ |title=Thom – Prasat Ta Moan – Ta Muen Temple – Ta Moan Temple – Prasat Ta Muen – Prasat Ta Moan – Khmer Temple Cambodia |publisher=Ta Moan |date=August 3, 2008 |accessdate=February 16, 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/index.php/2011042248663/Online-Edition/new-fighting-at-border.html |title=Search, Phnom Penh Post |publisher=Phnompenhpost.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} An agreement was reached in December 2011 to withdraw troops from the disputed area.{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-16294309 |work=BBC News | title=Thailand and Cambodia reach deal on temple border | date=December 21, 2011}} On 11 November 2013, the ICJ declared in a unanimous decision that the 1962 ICJ judgment had awarded all of the [[promontory]] of Preah Vihear to Cambodia and that Thailand had an obligation to withdraw any Thai military, police, or guard forces stationed in that area. However, it rejected Cambodia's argument that the judgment had also awarded the hill of Phnom Trap (three kilometers northwest of the temple) to Cambodia, finding that it had made no ruling on sovereignty over the hill. == Background == The Preah Vihear temple area has been the subject of often rancorous debate within Cambodia and Thailand and between the two countries since the late 19th century. The temple complex was built during the 9th and 10th centuries CE under the auspices of the [[Khmer Empire]]. As the empire reached its zenith and began a [[Dark ages of Cambodia#Cambodia's struggle for survival, 1432-1863|slow decline]], the [[Ayutthaya Kingdom]] began to grow into the modern state of Thailand. [[Siam]] and Vietnam [[Dark ages of Cambodia#Domination by Thailand and by Vietnam|expanded into]] Cambodian territory in turn during the Ayutthaya, [[Thonburi Kingdom|Thonburi]], and [[Rattanakosin Kingdom|Rattanakosin]] eras.{{citation needed|date = November 2013}} The [[Franco-Siamese War#Consequences|Franco-Siamese treaty of 1867]] forced Siam to renounce [[suzerainty]] over Cambodia, with the exception of [[Battambang Province (Thailand)|Battambang]], [[Siem Reap Province|Siem Reap]], [[Banteay Meanchey]], and [[Oddar Meancheay]] Provinces,[http://www.charnvitkasetsiri.com/PDF/PreahVihearFor20June.pdf Prasat Phra Viharn – Case study of political history – Nationalism], ''Page 5 of 15'' {{th icon}} which had been officially incorporated into the Kingdom of Siam. During the 1904 state visit of [[King Rama V]] to France, Siam agreed to cede the four provinces to France in exchange for regaining Thai sovereignty over [[Trat Province]] and [[Amphoe Dan Sai]] of [[Loei Province]], which had been occupied by France. In 1907 the Thai-Cambodian border was mapped by the French on behalf of a bilateral border commission. According to the 1904 agreement, the border would follow the natural watershed between the countries. However, the resulting map deviated by showing Preah Vihear Temple as being in Cambodia, even though it is on the Thai side of the watershed. Thailand accepted the map for official use. The Thais discovered the error when they made their own survey in the 1930s, but the ICJ ruled that they had waited too long to protest and lost the temple by "acquiesance".[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/45/4857.pdf ''Case Concerning the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand), Merits], [1962] I.C.J. Reports 6, p. 23'' Immediately prior to [[World War II]], the Thai government attempted to negotiate an adjustment of the border with [[French Indochina]]. However, this came to an end with the [[Battle of France#Surrender and armistice|French surrender in 1940]] to [[Nazi Germany]]. The government of Field Marshal Plaek Phibunsongkhram then pressed the colonial government of French Indochina for the return of territory Thailand had lost in the 1904 and 1907 exchanges: [[Battambang Province (Thailand)|Battambang Province]] of Thailand (modern day [[Battambang Province]] and [[Pailin]] municipality, Cambodia), [[Phibunsongkhram Province]] (modern day [[Siem Reap Province]], [[Oddar Meancheay Province]], and [[Banteay Meanchey Province]] Cambodia), [[Nakhon Champa Sak Province]] (modern day [[Champassack Province]], Laos, [[Preah Vihear Province]], Cambodia), and Saiyaburi Province of Laos (modern day [[Xaignabouli Province]], Laos); ''([[#External links|See map below]]) '' The French colonial government refused to comply and fighting broke out along the border. In December 1940, Phibunsongkhram ordered an outright invasion of French Indochina, starting the [[French-Thai War]]. The Thai army and air force was better equipped and had the advantage of numbers against the [[Vichy France|Colonial French]] forces; they pushed back the French Foreign Legion and French colonial troops with little difficulty. However, the more modern French Navy caught the Thai fleet by surprise and won a decisive victory in the [[Battle of Koh Chang]]. Imperial Japan intervened to mediate the conflict, concerned that the conflict would affect their own plans for Southeast Asia.'''Important events during the reign of King Rama VIII''' – Bangkok; E.Q. Plus adventure series, 2008. 160 pages. ISBN 978-974-06-9559-2 {{th icon}} A general [[armistice]] was declared on 28 January 1941. On 9 May a peace treaty was signed in Tokyo, the French being coerced by the Japanese into relinquishing their claim on the territories demanded by Thailand. [[Image:Preah Vihear Temple.png|thumb|200px|left|Map of Cambodia and Thailand, showing the location of the temple]] On 7 December 1941, a few hours before the [[attack on Pearl Harbor]], Japan demanded the right to move troops across Thailand to the Malayan frontier. Before the Thais could respond, the [[Japanese Invasion of Thailand]] began across the Cambodian border and at seven points along the sea coast. The Thai forces resisted, but were soon beaten by the Japanese. After only six or seven hours, Prime Minister [[Plaek Phibunsongkhram]] arrived in Bangkok and ordered an immediate ceasefire. Japan was reluctantly granted free passage, and after Japan's easy conquest of [[Singapore]], Phibunsongkhram signed a military alliance with Japan on 21 December 1941. It contained a secret protocol in which Tokyo agreed to help Thailand regain the territories it had lost to the [[British Empire|British]] and [[French colonial empire|French]] colonial powers. In exchange, Thailand promised to assist Japan in its war against the Allies. After the end of the war, Prime Minister [[Pridi Phanomyong]] agreed to return the "liberated" territories to France, in return for he and Thailand not being regarded as an aggressor nor a member of the [[Axis Power#Thailand|Axis Power]]s. He also requested admission to the newly created United Nations. Initially, both the UK and the [[Soviet Union]] regarded Thailand as an aggressor, despite its active anti-Japanese underground movement. The United States intervened in gratitude to the [[Free Thai Movement]] and prevailed on its wartime allies to agree. With [[Colonial Cambodia#Campaign for independence|Cambodian Independence]] and the French withdrawal in 1953, the Thai military occupied Preah Vihear Temple in 1954 in keeping with the border line of the natural watershed. The temple had been built facing north to serve the plains above it, not those of the Cambodian plain far below. However, based on the 1907 French map, Cambodia protested, insisting that it was inside their territory. Both countries finally agreed to submit the dispute to the International Court of Justice and abide by its decision. In 1962 the [[International Court of Justice|International Court of Justice (ICJ)]] awarded ownership of Preah Vihear Temple to Cambodia by a nine to three vote, stating the 1907 map clearly showed Preah Vihear as being in Cambodia.[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/45/4857.pdf ''Case Concerning the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand), Merits], [1962] I.C.J. Reports 6'' Nevertheless, the court had only ruled that the temple belong to Cambodia, and did not comment on the adjacent land to the north. Thailand reluctantly handed over the temple but continues to claim the surrounding area, insisting the border has never officially been demarcated here.{{cite web|url=http://www.preah-vihear.com|title=Preah-Vihear.com - Unesco's World Heritage site|publisher=Preah-vihear.com|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} The ownership dispute revived in recent years when Cambodia submitted an application to [[UNESCO]] requesting that Preah Vihear be designated as a [[World Heritage site]]. Thailand contended the application requested the designation include the land surrounding the temple, which Thailand still considers its territory. In the interest of cross-border relations Cambodia withdrew the application, and after winning support from Thailand, submitted a modified map requesting the designation only for the temple itself. The [[People's Alliance for Democracy]] (PAD), a right wing Thai protest group, turned the temple into a [[cause célèbre]] [[wedge issue]] in its battles against the [[People Power Party (Thailand)|People Power Party]] government of Prime Minister [[Samak Sundaravej]] in their attempts to unseat the former and current [[Cabinet of Thailand]].{{cite web|url = http://bangkokpost.net/090708_News/09Jul2008_news13.php |work=Bangkok Post | title =WHC plan for Preah Vihear 'most unusual' |accessdate =July 20, 2008|archiveurl=http://khmernz.blogspot.com/2008_07_09_archive.html |archivedate= July 9, 2008 |quote=WHC plan for Preah Vihear 'most unusual' }} In 2006 PAD-led street protests led first to the Thai general election of April 2006, largely boycotted by the opposition and won by then-incumbent Prime Minister [[Thaksin Shinawatra]]'s [[Thai Rak Thai]] Party. This was followed by the military coup of June 2006, which ousted Thaksin, the caretaker prime minister. Prime Minister Samak Sundaravej was viewed as a proxy for the self-exiled Thaksin Shinawatra, who now lives abroad to avoid conviction for corruption. Across the border, the [[Cambodian People's Party]] (CPP) government of Prime Minister [[Hun Sen]] used the possibly coincidental timing of [[UNESCO]]'s annual meeting and the listing of the temple as a [[World Heritage]] site in campaigning for the 27 July 2008 parliamentary election.{{Cite news|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7507425.stm |title = Political tensions driving temple row |accessdate =July 20, 2008 |last=Head |first=Jonathan |publisher=BBC News | date=July 15, 2008}} == Timeline == {{prose|date=November 2013}} === Lead-up to 2008 fighting === * In January 2008, the Thai Defense Ministry from the 56th Cabinet of Thailand protested Cambodia's attempt to register the temple as a UNESCO World Heritage Site without agreement from Thailand.{{cite web|url=http://news.sanook.com/social/social_239605.php |title=กลาโหม ล็อบบี้ทั่วโลกประณาม เขมร ชนวนระเบิดศึก เขาพระวิหาร ภาค 2 |publisher=News.sanook.com |accessdate=February 1, 2011}} * In March 2008, Cambodia informed Thailand of their plan to register Preah Vihear Temple as a World Heritage Site. * In April 2008, Thailand (the 57th cabinet) and Cambodia planned a talk on the issue before the registration. Thailand insisted that it would support the registration of the temple, but that the process "must not affect the disputed borderline".{{cite web|url = http://www.southeastasianarchaeology.com/2008/04/25/thailand-cambodia-and-unesco-meet-over-preah-vihear/ |title = Thailand, Cambodia and UNESCO meet over Preah Vihear | publisher=The Southeast Asian Archaeology Newsblog |accessdate =July 20, 2008}} * On 18 June 2008, Thailand and Cambodia issued a joint communique regarding the temple registration.{{cite web|url = http://nationmultimedia.com/2008/07/08/headlines/headlines_30077585.php |title = Joint communique with Cambodia is unconstitutional|accessdate =July 20, 2008|date=July 8, 2008|work=The Nation |location=Bangkok}} * On 22 June 2008, Cambodia closed the border crossing to Preah Vihear in response to Thai protests held at the border crossing. The protests were championed by an anti-Thaksin opposition figure, [[Sonthi Limthongkul]], who claimed the government of Thai Prime Minister Samak Sudaravej had gained business concessions in Cambodia in return for ceding Thai territory to Cambodia when negotiating over the Preah Vihear site map that would be presented to UNESCO in [[Quebec]], Canada.{{cite web|url = http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7011368406 |title = Cambodia Closes Border With Thailand At Preah Vihear Temple | publisher=AHN | date=July 20, 2008 |accessdate =July 20, 2008}} * On 20 June 2008 the ''Nation'' newspaper in Bangkok published an editorial online highly critical of the People's Alliance for Democracy for its use of Preah Vihear temple in its campaign against the People Power Party government of Prime Minister Samak Sudaravej.{{cite web|url = http://www.nationmultimedia.com/2008/06/30/politics/politics_30076876.php |title = Bangkok's Independent Newspaper |accessdate =July 20, 2008 |date = June 30, 2008 |last=Winichakul |first=Thongchai}} * On 2 July 2008, as UNESCO began its annual meeting in [[Quebec]], Canada, the ''Bangkok Post'' online published a Deutsche Presse-Agentur (German Press Agency) report that erroneously stated that Preah Vihear partially sits on Thai territory.{{cite web|url = http://www.bangkokpost.com/breaking_news/breakingnews.php?id=128686 |title = Bangkok Post Breaking News |accessdate =July 20, 2008}} Following the Thai government's decision to support Cambodia's bid for World Heritage listing, anti-Thaksin Shinawatra opposition figures mounted a legal challenge against Thai Foreign Minister [[Noppadon Pattama]]. ** The Thai Constitutional Court finally upheld the suit on 7 July 2008 in an eight to one judgment that the foreign minister's joint communique with Cambodia was "unconstitutional".{{Cite news|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/rbssInvestmentServices/idUSBKK2838520080709 |title = Thai rulings fuel election talk, PM not worried | publisher=Reuters |accessdate =July 20, 2008 | date=July 9, 2008}}{{cite web|url = http://enews.mcot.net/view.php?id=5126 |publisher=MCOT English News |title = Thai Court rules Thai-Cambodian communique in breach of charter |accessdate =July 20, 2008}} Whilst UNESCO met in Quebec, Canada, there were about 20 Thai people standing and protesting outside holding sign "Noppadon, you are a LIAR" and Thai flags. * On 8 July 2008, thousands of Phnom Penh residents marched through the streets in celebration of the inscription of Preah Vihear temple by UNESCO. On the same day, the Municipality of Phnom Penh held an evening outdoor concert at [[Wat Phnom]] to celebrate the inscription of Preah Vihear temple by UNESCO earlier in the day. The concert was nationally broadcast on [[Cambodian Television Network|CTN]], emceed by Cambodia's biggest television star and featured traditional Khmer performances as well as a fireworks display. Despite persistent rain, thousands of Cambodians attended. * On 10 July 2008, Thai Foreign Minister Nappadon Pattama resigned over the listing of Preah Vihear by UNESCO. His resignation followed the eight to one judgment by the Thai Constitutional Court that he had violated Article 190 of Thailand's 2007 Constitution, which calls for a public debate and cabinet-level approval before such authorization can take place.{{Cite news|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7499116.stm |title = Thailand foreign minister quits |accessdate =July 20, 2008 |publisher=BBC News | date=July 10, 2008}} * On 14 July 2008, 8,000 Cambodians filled [[Phnom Penh National Olympic Stadium|Phnom Penh's Olympic Stadium]] Indoor Arena for a concert hosted by Deputy Prime Minister [[Sok An]] and simulcast on [[Bayon Television]]. Sok An had just returned from UNESCO's annual conference in Quebec, Canada, where Preah Vihear was inscribed as a World Heritage site.{{cite web|url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-07/15/content_8545444.htm |title = Cambodia holds big concert to hail Preah Vihear temple as world heritage_English_Xinhua |accessdate =July 20, 2008}} * On 15 July 2008, cross-border tensions flared after Cambodian authorities arrested three Thai nationals who had attempted to plant the Thai flag near the temple. Cambodia claimed that several dozen Thai soldiers subsequently crossed the border. One Thai soldier lost his leg to a Cambodian landmine detonation.{{Cite news|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7506872.stm |title = Thai troops 'cross into Cambodia' |accessdate =July 20, 2008 |publisher=BBC News | date=July 15, 2008}}{{Cite news|url = http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5gU5d6jYmj-2GLu3WXVoep1qJ9HOw |title = Cambodian, Thai soldiers reportedly draw weapons |accessdate =July 20, 2008 |date = Jul 17, 2008 |agency=AFP}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/200708_News/20Jul2008_news002.php |title= The Real Victim At Preah Vihear |work=Bangkok Post |date=July 20, 2008 |accessdate=February 1, 2011}}{{dead link|date=February 2011}} ** Thailand maintains its troops are deployed to protect its sovereignty and ensure that any protests by Thais near the temple remain orderly, although a senior Thai military official acknowledged that his troops were on "disputed" ground. * On 16 July 2008, Thailand increased the number of troops stationed in the border region{{cite web|url = http://www.preah-vihear.com |last=Touch |first=Bora |title = Preah Vihear Temple and the Thai's Misunderstanding of the World Court Judgment of 15 June 1962 |date= June 29, 2008|accessdate =July 20, 2008}} adjacent to Preah Vihear temple. * On 17 July 2008, the total number of troops at the temple increased to over 1,000, with some of the 400 Thai troops in the area occupying a Buddhist pagoda near the temple and claimed by Cambodia. Thai forces denied they were inside Cambodian territory.{{Cite news|url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7511417.stm |title = Troop build-up at hill-top temple |accessdate =July 20, 2008 |publisher=BBC News | date=July 17, 2008}}{{Cite news|url=http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5h6tp2tO94iKNqIquUil4we_HH52QD91VEHA81 |title=The Associated Press: Cambodia, Thailand deploy more troops |accessdate=July 20, 2008 |date= |last=CHEANG |first=SOPHENG |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080731145517/http://ap.google.com/article/ALeqM5h6tp2tO94iKNqIquUil4we_HH52QD91VEHA81 |archivedate=July 31, 2008 }} ** In a letter to the Thai Prime Minister, Cambodian Prime Minister [[Hun Sen]] called for the immediate withdrawal of Thai troops and protesters from the area.{{Cite news|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/latestCrisis/idUSBKK41696 |title = Cambodia PM says Thai border row getting worse |agency=Reuters |accessdate =July 20, 2008 | date=July 17, 2008}} * On 18 July 2008, the Thai government handed Cambodia a letter from Prime Minister Samak Sundaravej insisting Thai troops are deployed on Thai soil. In a letter to Hun Sen, the Thai PM said Cambodian troops and buildings on the disputed {{convert|4.6|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} area were a "violation of Thailand's sovereignty and territorial integrity", but that his government was "resolved to seek a just and peaceful solution to the situation."{{cite web|url = http://www.bangkokpost.com/topstories/topstories.php?id=128939 |title = Bangkok Post: Top Stories |accessdate =July 20, 2008}}{{Cite news|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSBKK18950620080719 |title = More troops, rhetoric in Thai-Cambodia temple row | agency =Reuters |accessdate =July 20, 2008 | date=July 19, 2008}} * On 19 July 2008, the Thai and Cambodian governments sent more troops and heavy guns to the disputed border{{Cite news|url = http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2008/0719/breaking28.htm |title = More troops sent in Thai-Cambodia temple dispute |work=The Irish Times |date=July 19, 2008 |accessdate =July 20, 2008}} ahead of high-level talks scheduled for 21 July 2008 between the Cambodian defence minister and Thailand's supreme military commander.{{Cite news|url = http://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSBKK18950620080719?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 |title = More troops, rhetoric in Thai-Cambodia temple row | agency=Reuters |accessdate =July 20, 2008 | date=July 19, 2008}} * On 21 July 2008, Cambodian Defence Minister [[Tea Ban]] and Thai Army commander [[Boonsrang Niempradit]] held talks in Thailand. The talks achieved no outcome.{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-07/21/content_8742004.htm |title=Thai-Cambodia border meeting fails to meet breakthrough, but both promise no force_English_Xinhua |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=July 21, 2008 |accessdate=February 1, 2011}} * On 22 July 2008, Thailand rejected the assistance of ASEAN in resolving the border dispute. Thailand's statement came as ASEAN foreign ministers began a meeting in Singapore. The BBC reported that Cambodia had requested UN assistance in resolving the border dispute. The previous week the Cambodian government denied it had made such a call after similar news stories were published.{{Cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/7518741.stm |publisher=BBC News | title=UN help sought over temple row | date=July 22, 2008 | accessdate=April 28, 2010}} * On 23 July 2008, a spokesman for Cambodia's prime minister suggested that Cambodia may take the case to the [[International Court of Justice]], as was done in 1962. * On 24 July 2008, Cambodia announced it would postpone its request to the United Nations until the bilateral negotiation at [[Siem Reap]] on 28 July was finished. ** Cambodia and Thailand held the meeting on 28 July without any results. ** Reportedly, both sides are in favour of a troop withdrawal, beginning with Thailand's army; the date when Thailand would withdraw its troops was not agreed on, however.{{cite web|url=http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/news/stories/200807/s2318239.htm?tab=latest |title=ABC Radio Australia News |publisher=Radioaustralia.net.au |date=September 26, 2010 |accessdate=February 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081013121640/http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/news/stories/200807/s2318239.htm?tab=latest |archivedate=October 13, 2008 }} * On 1 August 2008, [[Bun Rany]], wife of Cambodian Prime Minister [[Hun Sen]], conducted a Buddhist ritual at the temple; thousands of Cambodians also joined the ritual. On the same night, the anti-Thai government People's Alliance for Democracy (PAD) led thousands of their supporters in a rival ritual, by praying [[Sūtra|Sutta]]s that the [[Gautama Buddha]] gave to his monks; they claimed this was to prevent any negative effects from the Cambodian ritual. Many Thais accused Bun Rany of conducting black magic aimed to weaken Thailand.{{cite web |url= http://www.bangkokpost.com/020808_News/02Aug2008_news01.php |title=Hun Sen's wife hosts huge Preah Vihear temple ritual |publisher=Bangkok Post}} {{dead link|date=February 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/8/9/focus/22040412 |title=Peace vigil, black magic and sabre-rattling over a temple |publisher=The Star Online |date=August 9, 2008 |accessdate=August 9, 2011}}{{cite news |title="Black Khmer magic" a threat to the Thai army?! |last=Saiyasombut |first=Saksith |url=http://asiancorrespondent.com/48727/black-khmer-magic-a-threat-to-the-thai-army/ |newspaper= Siam Voices |date= February 20, 2011 |accessdate=October 3, 2011 | quote= A Thai soldier wears an amulet on the outside of his bullet proof vest along with ammunition as he takes up a position across from an anti-government barriade near Lumpini Park in downtown Bangkok, Thailand, Wednesday, 19 May 2010. accessdate=April 28, 2010}} * On 5 August 2008, Kriengkrai Sampatchalit, [[Thailand Fine Arts Department]] director replied to Cambodia, claiming that "The Prasat Ta Moan Thom Temple is located just The observer team will be unarmed," Indonesian Foreign Minister [[Marty Natalegawa]] said.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12534980 |title=Thailand and Cambodia to accept monitors for border row |date=February 22, 2011 |work=News Asia-Pacific|publisher=BBC |accessdate=February 23, 2011}} ==== April–May 2011 ==== * On 7 April, Thailand admitted using [[Dual-Purpose Improved Conventional Munition]] (DPICM) during the clash, which has been identified by the [[Cluster Munition Coalition]] (CMC) as a type of [[cluster munition]].{{Cite news |url= https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gW7qVEGjRxN5o0AIFKdMhVFPnqCw?docId=CNG.285b5f9b8539f4a92d911152e3a6184e.f1 |title= Thailand admits controversial weapon use|date= April 7, 2011|work=News|agency=Agence France-Presse }} These contain up to hundreds of small grenades or "bomblets" that scatter over vast areas, and are banned by the majority of countries under the [[Convention on Cluster Munitions]]. Thailand has not signed the pact, but has publicly pledged not to use such weapons.[http://www.kplctv.com/story/14500578/cambodia-says-fighting-resumes-along-thai-border Cambodia says fighting resumes along Thai border], ''KPLC TV''. The CMC said this was the first confirmed use of cluster munitions since the convention became international law. * On 22 April, a five-hour clash erupted along the border between Phanom Dong Rak District of [[Surin Province]], Thailand and the [[Banteay Ampil]] District of [[Oddar Meanchey]] Province, Cambodia at the Ta Moan temple complex {{coord|14|20|57|N|103|15|59|E|}} {{convert|153|km}} west of Preah Vihear and at Ta Krabey temple complex {{convert|15|km}} east of Ta Moan, with reports that both sides used rocket launchers, machine guns, and rifles. According to the Thai army, the fighting erupted after dawn and continued for over half an hour. Four Thai and three Cambodian soldiers were reported killed and eight Thai and six Cambodian soldiers were reported wounded.{{cite web|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/42713060/ns/world_news/ |accessdate=April 22, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501131708/http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/42713060/ns/world_news/ |archivedate=May 1, 2011 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/breakingnews/233213/update-4-soldiers-killed-8-wounded|title=Bangkok Post : The world windows to Thailand|work=Bangkok Post|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} * On 23 April 2011, the fighting with mostly long-distance shelling resumed about 06:00 and halted by noon. A Cambodian defence ministry statement accused Thai aircraft of entering Cambodian airspace. The statement also said Thai forces had fired 75- and 105-mm shells loaded with [[poisonous gas]] into Cambodia's territory, an allegation that could not be independently verified and that Thailand rejected. A Cambodian field commander claimed that the "poison smoke" caused several soldiers who inhaled it to lose strength in their arms and legs. Col. Suos Sothea, deputy commander of the artillery unit, said that six rounds of cluster shells had landed in villages about {{convert|20|km|mi|abbr=on}} inside Cambodia, but caused no casualties since residents had already been evacuated. Col. Tawatchai Samutsakorn, commander of Thailand's 2nd Army Region, denied absolutely that cluster bombs or poison gas had been employed. Tawatchai said one Thai soldier died, bringing the two-day casualty toll to four dead and 17 wounded, and that 15,000 civilians had been evacuated from the area of fighting. Cambodia's Suos Sothea said three soldiers from his country had been killed, bringing Cambodia's two-day death toll to six. According to vice-president of the Cambodian National Committee for Disaster Management, Mr [[Nhim Vanda]], roughly 5,000 residents had been evacuated to a safe shelter in the [[Samraong (town)|Samrong]] district of [[Banteay Meanchey]] Province, some {{convert|30|km}} from the fighting zone.[http://www.smh.com.au/world/gun-battle-resumes-on-thai-border-20110423-1ds6p.html Gun battle resumes on Thai border], ''Sydney Morning Herald''.{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-04/23/c_13842750.htm|title=Xinhua.net|publisher=Xinhuanet.com|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} * On 25 April, the fighting continued, after an almost full-day break. * On 26 April the fighting resumed for a fifth day. The fighting had now spread to a nearby temple.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-13192513|title=BBC News – Thai-Cambodia clashes spread east to Preah Vihear|work=BBC News|accessdate=October 17, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/khmer-english/news/Border-Clashes-Spread-as-Leaders-Talk-of-Ceasefire-120692644.html|title=VoaNews – Border Clashes Spread as Leaders Talk of Ceasefire|work=VOA|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} By this point, five Thai soldiers were killed and more than 35 wounded, and eight Cambodian soldiers were killed, 17 were wounded and one was missing.{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jJn8xO17x_XAkjKoCey0zHOfsnmw?docId=CNG.ce5e2e67a61454295cd54a08b0ebf3f2.851 |title=AFP: Thailand, Cambodia eye truce as fighting spreads |publisher=Google.com |date=2011-04-26 |accessdate=2013-11-14}}http://www.sharenet.co.za/news/Thai_Cambodia_troops_clash_again_peace_talks_sought/946aa458a37b896ef62caf41328eb60f{{cite web|url=http://www.pattayadailynews.com/en/2011/04/25/over-12-killed-in-thai-cambodian-border-clash/ |title=Over 12 killed in Thai-Cambodian Border Clash | Pattaya Daily News - Pattaya Newspaper, Powerful news at your fingertips |publisher=Pattaya Daily News |date=2011-04-25 |accessdate=2013-11-14}} * On 27 April, a Thai civilian was reported to had been killed in the fighting.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalmontreal.com/world/Thailand+pulls+truce+talks+with+Cambodia/4675612/story.html |title=Global News | Latest & Current News - Weather, Sports & Health News |publisher=Globalmontreal.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} * On 28 April, two more Thai soldiers were confirmed killed in the fighting.{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/234212/border-clash-kills-another-thai-soldier|title=Bangkok Post : The world windows to Thailand|publisher=Bangkokpost.com|accessdate=October 17, 2014}}{{cite news|url=http://www.forbes.com/feeds/ap/2011/04/28/general-as-thailand-cambodia-clash_8440886.html |work=Forbes |title=Thai, Cambodia clashes continue despite cease-fire |date=April 28, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} The same day, Thailand and Cambodia agreed upon a ceasefire. Cambodian spokesman Phay Siphan said that ''"We will abide by the ceasefire from now on and local commanders will meet regularly to avoid misunderstanding"''.{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=218196 |accessdate=April 29, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110428081541/http://www.jpost.com/Headlines/Article.aspx?id=218196 |archivedate=April 28, 2011 }} * On 29 April, the ceasefire was broken, as one Thai soldier was confirmed killed in the fighting.{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-13234944 |work=BBC News | title=Thai-Cambodia clashes resume despite truce | date=April 29, 2011}} A Thai military spokesmen said 11 Thai soldiers were hurt in the clashes with a total of 58 soldiers wounded since the start of the fighting.{{cite web|last=Nation |first=The |url=http://www.nationmultimedia.com/home/Soldier-and-civilian-killed-in-fresh-fighting-30154199.html |title=Soldier and civilian killed in fresh fighting |publisher=Nationmultimedia.com |date=2011-04-29 |accessdate=2013-11-14}} * On 30 April, the fighting resumed for a ninth day. However, there were no casualties.{{cite web|url=http://nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/International/30-Apr-2011/Thailand-Cambodia-clash-for-9th-day-16-dead|title=Thailand, Cambodia clash for 9th day, 16 dead|work=The Nation|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} * On 1 May, a Cambodian soldier was killed. The death toll had reached 17, including: nine Cambodian and seven Thai soldiers and one Thai civilian. Ninety-five Thais, including 50 soldiers, and 18 Cambodian servicemen had been wounded since the start of the fighting.{{cite web|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2014925849_apasthailandcambodiaclash.html?syndication=rss|title=Thai, Cambodian troops clash again at border|work=The Seattle Times|accessdate=October 17, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://ph.news.yahoo.com/10-thai-troops-injured-light-weapons-clashes-border-094003632.html|title=10 Thai troops injured after 'light weapons' clashes on border|date=May 1, 2011|work=Yahoo News Philippines|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} According to Thai army spokesman Col. Prawit Hukaew, the two sides had engaged each other with automatic weapons overnight Sunday. According to Thailand, no Thai troops was killed in the clashes.{{cite web|url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2014925028_apasthailandcambodiaclash.html|title=The Seattle Times – Thai, Cambodian troops clash again at border|work=The Seattle Times|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} In the afternoon, the Cambodian Ministry of Defense issued a statement which condemned Thailand for ten straight days of armed conflict; ''"The repeated invasions of Thai troops into Cambodia have caused gradual damage to Cambodia, it is an unacceptable act"''.{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-05/01/c_13854296.htm|title=English.news.cn – Cambodia's army condemns Thailand for 10 straight days of arms attacks|publisher=Xinhuanet.com|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} * On 2 May, the two sides engaged each other with automatic fire, but no casualties was reported.[http://www.chinapost.com.tw/asia/thailand/2011/05/02/300767/Thai-Cambodian.htm The China Post – Thai, Cambodian troops clash again at border] Cambodia also filed a case at the [[International Court of Justice]] on that day.{{cite web|url=http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/index.php?p1=3&p2=1&code=ct2&case=151&k=89 |title=Pending Cases | International Court of Justice |publisher=Icj-cij.org |date=1962-06-15 |accessdate=2013-11-14}} * On 3 May, a Thai soldier was killed during skirmish in Surin, bringing the death toll on the Thai side to 12.http://www.bernama.com/bernama/v5/newsgeneral.php?id=583555 Cambodia claimed Thailand had fired 50,000 shells during the clashes.{{cite web|url=http://www.taiwannews.com.tw/etn/news_content.php?id=1587342|title=Taiwan News – Cambodia says Thailand shot 50,000 shells in clash|publisher=Taiwannews.com.tw|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} * On 4 May, a ceasefire was agreed upon, and the border was re-opened for trade.[http://hken.ibtimes.com/articles/141610/20110505/thai-cambodia-ceasefire-war-clashes-asean.htm International Business News – Thai, Cambodian armies agree to ceasefire, borders opened for trade] {{dead link|date=October 2014}} * On 5 May, Thai Prime Minister [[Abhisit Vejjajiva]] made it clear that he would not allow any international troops at Preah Vihear, unless Cambodia withdrew its forces from the disputed territory. He claimed the presence of troops in the area was a violation of the 2000 memorandum of understanding between Thailand and Cambodia.{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/generalnewsfeed/news/no-border-observers-until-cambodia-withdraws-troops-thai-pm/672731.html|title=Ibn Live – No border observers until Cambodia withdraws troops: Thai PM|publisher=Ibnlive.in.com|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} * On 7 May, Thailand and Cambodia agreed to appoint Indonesia as observers at the disputed border.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/khmer-english/news/Thailand-Cambodia-Agree-to-Indonesian-Observers-at-Border-121435349.html|title=VOA: Thailand, Cambodia Agree to Indonesian Observers at Border|work=VOA|accessdate=October 17, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2012/01/17/ri-ready-send-observers-cambodia-thailand.html|title=The Jakarta Post: RI ready to send observers to Cambodia, Thailand|publisher=Thejakartapost.com|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} ==== July 2011 ==== *Following a request from Cambodia to order Thai troops out of the area, the judges of the [[International Court of Justice]] by a vote of 11–5 ordered both countries to immediately to withdraw their military forces from disputed areas straddling their border and imposed restrictions on both their armies and police forces. A "provisional demilitarized zone" would make Thai troops leave positions they have long occupied and Cambodia's to leave the temple's immediate vicinity. The court also called for officers from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) to be allowed into the area to observe the cease-fire as called for by the UN Security Council last February. :Both sides said they were satisfied with the decision. Thai Foreign Minister Kasit, speaking outside the court, said that a withdrawal of armed Cambodians from the temple complex "has been our consistent position." Further noting that the decision is binding on both countries, he added that Thailand would withdraw its forces and facilitate the observers' deployment, and further agreed to allow unhindered supplies to Cambodian civilian personnel at the temple complex. :[[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation (Cambodia)|Cambodian Foreign Minister]] [[Hor Namhong]] said a demilitarised zone would mean "a permanent cease-fire...tantamount to a cessation of aggression" by Thailand. He also said he was satisfied with the dispatch of truce observers, which he said Cambodia had been seeking since last February, but made no reference to the demand for Cambodian troops to abandon the temple grounds. :The court said its ruling would not prejudice any final ruling on where the border in the area between Thailand and Cambodia should fall. It could take the court many months or even years to reach that decision.{{cite news |title=UN orders troops away from temple |url= http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/un-orders-troops-away-from-temple-2315713.html|work=The Independent |date=July 18, 2011 | at=Asia |accessdate=July 18, 2011 |location=London}} :Abhisit, caretaker prime minister since the just-concluded [[Thai general election, 2011|Thai general election]], said that Thai soldiers would not pull out of the disputed area until the military of both countries agreed on the mutual withdrawal. "We need to talk to the Cambodians as the Cambodians also have to pull out their troops," Abhisit said at a news conference in Bangkok. "So there has to be some kind of mechanism to verify, to do it in an orderly manner. And therefore it depends on the two sides to come together and talk," he said, suggesting that an existing joint border committee would be the appropriate place to plan a coordinated pullback.{{cite news |title=UN court draws DMZ for Thai, Cambodia troops |last=Max |first=Arthur |url=http://www.sfexaminer.com/news/2011/07/un-court-draws-dmz-thai-cambodia-troops | agency=AP |newspaper=The San Francisco Examiner |date=July 18, 2011 |accessdate=July 18, 2011}} *On 23 July, one Cambodian soldier was killed along the Cambodian-Thai border while another was wounded. A local military commander stated that the soldier's death was a result of clashes provoked by Thai troops. Pok Sophal, a commander for Oddar Meanchey's Trapaing Prasat district, stated that, "We had an appointment for the meeting [between the two sides], and when we were walking, they opened fire at our soldiers". Thai spokesman Phay Siphan stated that the government was investigating the incident, but dismissed claims of armed clashes.{{cite web|url=http://www.phnompenhpost.com/index.php/2011072550610/National-news/soldier-dead-at-border.html|title=Phnom Penh Post – Soldier dead at border|work=Phnom Penh Post|accessdate=October 17, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://khmerization.blogspot.com/2011/07/one-cambodian-soldier-killed-in-clash.html|title=Khmerization – One Cambodian soldier killed in clash with Thai troops |publisher=Khmerization.blogspot.com|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} ==== September 2011 ''Football diplomacy'' ==== {{see also|Sports diplomacy}} The Thai general election resulted in a decisive victory for the [[Pheu Thai Party]], with their leader, [[Yingluck Shinawatra]], replacing Abhist as [[Prime Minister of Thailand|Prime Minister]] on 5 August 2011. Many [[United Front for Democracy Against Dictatorship]] (UDD, also called "Red Shirts") members were elected to the [[House of Representatives of Thailand|House of Representatives]]. Core UDD leaders arranged with Cambodian PM Hun Sen for a friendly [[Association football|football]] match to be played in Phnom Penh's Olympic Stadium on 24 September.{{cite news |title= Thai red shirts to initiate football policy with Cambodia |url= http://www.cambodiagateway.com/news/government/thai-red-shirts-to-initiate-football-policy-with-cambodia/451 |agency = [[Xinhua]] |newspaper= Cambodia Gateway |date= September 2011|accessdate=September 27, 2011 | quote = Pheu Thai lawmakers and red-shirt leaders are going to play a friendly football match with a Cambodian government team in Phnom Penh on Sept. 24, local media reported.}} MP–and–UDD leaders [[Jatuporn Prompan]] and [[Natthawut Saikua]] were prohibited from leaving the country due to pending charges arising from the [[2010 Thai political protests]], so an attorney petitioned the Criminal Court for permission for them to travel to Cambodia for the game.{{cite news |title= UDD-Cambodia football match expected to hasten release of Thai detainees|last=Laotharanarit |first=Surapan |url= |newspaper= National News Bureau of Thailand|id=News ID: 255409100006 |date= September 10, 2011|accessdate=September 27, 2011 |quote= UDD core figures, such as Mr Natthawut Saikua, Mr Jatuporn Prompan, MD Weng Tojirakarn and Mr Korkaew Pikulthong, are still prohibited from leaving the country, an attorney has been assigned to petition the Criminal Court for permission for the individuals to travel to Cambodia for the game.}} Former Thai premier [[Somchai Wongsawat]] led the Thai side. Cambodian premier Hun Sen led his side to a 10–7 victory, following which he announced that "the nightmare era" between Thailand and Cambodia was over. Former Foreign Minister Kasit Piromya rejoined that Hun Sen should not think that he could benefit from close ties with ousted former Thai Premier Thaksin Shinawatra and the ruling Pheu Thai Party. "Don't think that you will get at our natural resources and territory by be-friending or playing football with the Pheu Thai MPs," he said.{{cite news |title = Soccer match heals wounds |last1=Sattaburuth |first1=Aekarach |first2=Thanida |last2=Tansubhapol |agency=AFP |url= http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/local/258145/soccer-match-heals-wounds |work= Bangkok Post |date= September 25, 2011 |accessdate=February 28, 2011 | quote= Hun Sen Declares Thai-Cambodian 'Nightmare' Over }} ==== December 2011 ==== On 15 December, armies of both sides exchanged gunfire along the border in [[Koh Kong Province]]. The armed clash erupted at 13:45 in Zone 329 in [[Ta Min mountain]] after a Thai helicopter tried to land in Cambodian territory. No injuries or deaths were reported. The source said the Cambodian soldiers opened fire to prevent the Thai helicopter entering Cambodia and that the Thai soldiers responded with heavy gunfire. It was the first armed clash since Thailand's new government was formed in August.{{cite web|title=Biên giới Cam – Thái lại vang tiếng súng|work=Viet bao.com|date=December 16, 2011|url=http://vietbao.vn/The-gioi/Bien-gioi-Cam-Thai-lai-vang-tieng-sung/75315839/159/|language=Vietnamese|accessdate=December 16, 2011}} ==Proceedings at the International Court of Justice== [[File:Provisional demilitarised zone - icj - 18 july 2011 - 001.jpg|Provisional demilitarized zone pursuant to the Order of 18 July 2011|300px|right|thumb]] On 28 April 2011 Cambodia filed a request for interpretation of the 1962 judgment, as well as a request for the indication of [[Provisional measure of protection|provisional measures]], in the Registry of the [[International Court of Justice]].{{cite web|url=http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/151/17704.pdf|format=PDF|title=Request for Interpretation of the Judgment of 15 June 1962 in the Case concerning the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand) ''(Cambodia v. Thailand), Merits'', para 1|publisher=Icj-cij.org|accessdate=17 October 2014}} On 18 July 2011 the court rejected Thailand's attempt to have the case dismissed and indicated provisional measures requiring both states to withdraw their soldiers from a "provisional demilitarized zone" containing the area in dispute and some of its environs, continue their co-operation with ASEAN and observers appointed by it, and refrain from doing anything that might "aggravate or extend the dispute".''Request for Interpretation of the Judgment of 15 June 1962 in the Case concerning'' the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand) ''(Cambodia v. Thailand), Provisional Measures, I.C.J. Reports 2011 (II)'', pp. 555-556, para. 69, points B.1, B.3 and B.4 of the operative part.[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/151/16564.pdf] It also ordered Thailand not to obstruct Cambodia's access to the Temple of Preah Vihear.[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/151/16564.pdf ''Request for Interpretation of the Judgment of 15 June 1962 in the Case concerning'' the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand) ''(Cambodia v. Thailand), Provisional Measures, I.C.J. Reports 2011 (II)'', pp. 555-556, para. 69, point B.2 of the operative part.] On 11 November 2013 the International Court of Justice gave judgment, ruling that the 1962 judgment awarded all of the [[promontory]] to Cambodia and ordering the withdrawal of Thai soldiers.''Request for Interpretation of the Judgment of 15 June 1962 in the Case concerning'' the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand) ''(Cambodia v. Thailand), Merits'', para 108, point 2 of the operative part.[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/151/17704.pdf] This followed a tense buildup to the decision in which dozens of Thai schools had closed ahead of the ruling.{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia-pacific/2013/11/un-rule-thai-cambodian-border-row-201311116485209849.html |title=UN rules for Cambodia in Thai border row - Asia-Pacific |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} The court first concluded that it had jurisdiction and the request for interpretation was admissible, finding that a "dispute exists between the Parties as to the meaning and scope of the 1962 judgment pursuant to Article 60 of the Statute [of the ICJ]."''Request for Interpretation of the Judgment of 15 June 1962 in the Case concerning'' the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand) ''(Cambodia v. Thailand), Merits'', para 57.[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/151/17704.pdf] The court said that the 1962 judgment had three important features:''Request for Interpretation of the Judgment of 15 June 1962 in the Case concerning'' the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand) ''(Cambodia v. Thailand), Merits'', para 76.[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/151/17704.pdf] it involved an issue of "territorial sovereignty...and that it was not engaged in delimiting the frontier"; the "Annex I map played a central role in the reasoning of the Court...";''Request for Interpretation of the Judgment of 15 June 1962 in the Case concerning'' the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand) ''(Cambodia v. Thailand), Merits'', para 77.[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/151/17704.pdf] and that it made clear that it was only dealing with the small area in the "region of the Temple of Preah Vihear".''Request for Interpretation of the Judgment of 15 June 1962 in the Case concerning'' the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand) ''(Cambodia v. Thailand), Merits'', para 78.[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/151/17704.pdf] The court unanimously declared:''Request for Interpretation of the Judgment of 15 June 1962 in the Case concerning'' the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand) ''(Cambodia v. Thailand), Merits'', para 107.[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/151/17704.pdf]
The Court therefore concludes that the first operative paragraph of the 1962 Judgment determined that Cambodia had sovereignty over the whole territory of the promontory of Preah Vihear, as defined in paragraph 98 of the present Judgment, and that, in consequence, the second operative paragraph required Thailand to withdraw from that territory the Thai military or police forces, or other guards or keepers, that were stationed there.
However, the court rejected Cambodia's argument that Phnom Trap had also been awarded to it by the 1962 judgment, concluding that the reference to the "vicinity" of the Temple of Preah Vihear in the operative part of the 1962 judgment was not intended to extend to it. Phnom Trap, known by Thais as Phu Ma-khuea (ภูมะเขือ, "[[Solanum]] Hill"), is the hill three kilometers northwest of the temple and comprises over 4 km2 of the "4.6 square km" that both states agreed was in dispute.''Request for Interpretation of the Judgment of 15 June 1962 in the Case concerning'' the Temple of Preah Vihear (Cambodia v. Thailand) ''(Cambodia v. Thailand), Merits'', para 92.[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/151/17704.pdf] Prior to the verdict, hundreds of Thai villagers left the area in expectation of the ruling to be unfavorable to them. There were also fears of renewed clashes amid rising nationalist rhetoric.{{cite web|last=Sattar |first=Maher |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2013/11/ruling-doesn-quell-thai-cambodia-border-row-2013111312207531747.html |title=Ruling doesn't quell Thai-Cambodia border row - Features |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} == Civilian effects == After the initial attack on 4 February 2011, the Cambodian army fired [[BM-21 Grad]] rockets into the town of Sao Thong Chai about {{convert|5|km}} from the border. As a direct result, primary schools, a local hospital, and four or five houses were destroyed.{{cite web|url=http://www.manager.co.th/Home/ViewNews.aspx?NewsID=9540000016125 |title= ร่ำไห้หนัก!! สาวภูมิซรอลพบบ้านถูกปืนใหญ่เขมรยิงใส่พังยับ – มท.พร้อมเยียวยา |publisher=Manager.co.th |accessdate=February 16, 2011}} Only minutes before the bombardment, the local authority had issued a warning to the locals to evacuate and close the school. Despite this, one civilian was killed and at least 34 were injured in the rocket attack.{{cite web|url=http://www.manager.co.th/Home/ViewNews.aspx?NewsID=9540000016656 |title= สธ.เผยเหตุปะทะชายแดนไทย-กัมพูชา มีผู้เสียชีวิต 2 ราย เจ็บ 34 ราย |publisher=Manager.co.th |accessdate=February 16, 2011}} There are reports that 22,000 Thai citizens had to evacuate and abandon their homes. The Cambodian government blamed the Thai army for firing onto the World Heritage temple, causing severe damage, whereas the Cambodian army settled the site as an army base. There is evidence, such as video and photo footage from Reuters,{{Cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/slideshow/idUSTRE71409020110205#a=1 |title=Images showing Cambodian troop use Preah Vihear temple as a military base |publisher=Reuters |date= February 5, 2011|accessdate=February 16, 2011}} showing that Cambodian forces used the temple as a military base and fired machine guns and artillery. Thai soldiers responded by firing rifles at the Cambodian soldiers hiding in the temple.{{cite web|url=http://www.manager.co.th/IndoChina/ViewNews.aspx?NewsID=9540000015969 |title=IndoChina – Manager Online – ฉีกหน้ากากแขมร์ เขมรใช้ปราสาทพระวิหารกำบัง เป็นที่ตั้งทหาร-ปืนกล |publisher=Manager.co.th |accessdate=February 16, 2011}} However, there are only a few bullet impacts visible on the temple.{{cite web|url=http://www.manager.co.th/IndoChina/ViewNews.aspx?NewsID=9540000015960 |title= เขมรเวอร์จริง บันไดนาคโดนสะเก็ดถลอก แต่โวยวายพระวิหารใกล้พัง |publisher=Manager.co.th |accessdate=February 16, 2011}} The Associated Press reported that Cambodian troops were stationed in the temple.{{Cite news|first=Todd |last=Pitman |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.startribune.com/world/115550984.html?elr=KArksDyycyUtyycyUiD3aPc:_Yyc:aUokEya_tyycy_eEQDU |title=Cambodia has troops bunkered at World Heritage temple, despite denial that soldiers are there |work=Star Tribune |date=February 9, 2011 |accessdate=February 16, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Thai army was accused of using cluster munitions against Cambodia during the border fighting in February. Thailand at first denied the allegation, but later admitted it had fired the weapons. According to the Cluster Munition Coalition, thousands of Cambodian villagers are now at risk of death or serious injury because of unexploded ordnance near their homes.{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12983127 |title=Thailand 'admits cluster bombs used against Cambodia' |work=BBC News |date=April 6, 2011 |accessdate=June 29, 2011}} == Reactions == === International === Many Asian nations, including [[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]], the [[Philippines]], [[Japan]], [[China]], and [[Vietnam]], as well as Canada, Russia, the United Kingdom, and the United States, have called on both sides to exercise restraint.{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/asiapcf/07/22/thailand.cambodia/index.html |title=Thai-Cambodia dispute moves to ASEAN |publisher=CNN |accessdate=February 7, 2011 |date=July 22, 2008}}[//www.youtube.com/watch?v=D8Qc5iloOjA Cambodia No. 53 – News : fighting in Preah Vihear] – October 15, 2008. [http://www.webcitation.org/5gwseyyTK Archived] May 21, 2009.{{Unreliable source?|date=February 2011}}[http://nguyentandung.org/doi-ngoai/viet-nam-keu-goi-campuchia-va-thai-lan-kiem-che.html Việt Nam kêu gọi Campuchia và Thái Lan kiềm chế] {{vi}}{{cite news|title=U.S. urges maximum restraint in Thailand-Cambodia border conflict|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-02/05/c_13719796.htm|publisher=XinHua}}{{cite web|url=http://www.international.gc.ca/media/aff/news-communiques/2011/055.aspx?view=d|title=Statement by Minister Cannon on Clashes at Thai-Cambodian Border|publisher=International.gc.ca|accessdate=October 17, 2014}} Thailand and Cambodia agreed to allow Indonesian monitors to go to the border between the two countries to help prevent further military clashes; Indonesia was appointed as observer in this dispute. === Local === [[File:BombShelter.JPG|thumb|Improvised village [[bunker]]]]Despite the 1976 [[Treaty of Amity and Cooperation in Southeast Asia]], which commits parties to resolve intrastate conflict without violence, and the 2000 [[Memorandum of Understanding]] between Cambodia and Thailand, which established a Joint Border Commission to peacefully resolve overlapping claims, important constituent groups in Thailand, including the "Yellow Shirts," maintain that the status of Preah Vihear remains unresolved.{{cite web |url=http://the-diplomat.com/asean-beat/2011/05/24/china-and-the-thai-cambodia-spat/ |title=China and Thai-Cambodia Spat |last=Walsh |first=Eddie |date=May 24, 2011 |work=[[The Diplomat]] |accessdate=July 25, 2011}} Villagers from Ban Phum Srol denounced plans by the [[People's Alliance for Democracy]] (PAD) ("Yellow Shirts") to bring relief supplies. "You have created the war. You troubled us. We don't welcome you," said Wichit Duangkaew, 46.{{cite web |url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asia/220756/villagers-rally-to-call-on-pad-to-stay-away |title=Villagers rally to call on PAD to stay away |last=Nanuam |first=Wassana |date=February 10, 2011 |work=[[Bangkok Post]] |accessdate=February 10, 2011}} Police arrested a Thai, a Cambodian, and a Vietnamese in [[Sisaket Province|Sisaket's]] Kantharalak district, near the Thai-Cambodian border.
